IV. Legal implications of latent conditions

When latent conditions are discovered during the construction process, it can have significant legal implications for both homeowners and builders. Builders may claim additional costs for remedying the latent conditions, and homeowners may be faced with unexpected delays or expenses.

In NSW, the Home Building Act 1989 sets out specific requirements for builders and homeowners in relation to latent conditions. Builders are required to provide written notice of any latent conditions before the construction process begins, and homeowners have a right to terminate the contract if they do not agree to pay for the additional costs associated with the latent conditions.

However, if the latent condition was not reasonably foreseeable, builders may be entitled to claim additional costs for remedying the issue. In these cases, it's important for homeowners to seek legal advice to ensure their rights are protected.

Homeowners may also have legal recourse if they can prove that the builder was aware of the latent condition and failed to disclose it or take reasonable steps to address it.

Overall, understanding the legal implications of latent conditions is crucial for both homeowners and builders to ensure that the construction process runs smoothly and disputes can be resolved quickly and fairly.
